query_summary: Analyze the drop in ROAS across Facebook Ads campaigns.

data_context.key_observation: The average ROAS is 10.41, but the analysis seeks to understand what might be causing it to drop for certain campaigns or ad sets.
data_context.variance_observed: The query implies a decrease in ROAS compared to a previous period. The analysis is to find the causes of this drop.

hypotheses.title: Audience Fatigue in Retargeting Adsets
hypotheses.description: Retargeting adsets (Adset-1 Retarget, Adset-2 Retarget, Adset-4 Retarget, Adset-5 Retarget) are experiencing audience fatigue, leading to a lower ROAS. Users repeatedly exposed to the same ads become less likely to convert.
hypotheses.testable_prediction: Retargeting adsets will have a lower CTR and ROAS compared to other audience types (Broad, Lookalike). The ROAS will be lower in the analysis period compared to the comparison period specifically for retargeting adsets.
supporting_evidence: Data includes 'Retargeting' as an audience type.
Audience fatigue is a common marketing phenomenon.
counterevidence: If retargeting ROAS is higher than other audience types, this hypothesis is invalid.
If CTR for retargeting adsets has not declined.
hypotheses.confidence_reasoning: Retargeting audiences are smaller and more prone to fatigue. It is likely a contributing factor, especially if the creative hasn't been refreshed.

hypotheses.title: Creative Decay in Video Ads
hypotheses.description: Video ads are experiencing creative decay. The initial novelty has worn off, resulting in a lower CTR and ROAS.
hypotheses.testable_prediction: Video ads will have a significantly lower ROAS and CTR compared to image or carousel ads in the analysis period. ROAS for video ads will have declined more than other creative types compared to the comparison period.
supporting_evidence: Data includes 'Video' as a creative type.
Creative decay is a common issue with video and UGC ads.
counterevidence: If video ads perform better than other creative types.
If ROAS decline is similar across all creative types.
hypotheses.confidence_reasoning: Video ads often have a strong initial impact but can quickly become stale. This is particularly true if the video content is not frequently updated.

hypotheses.title: Increased Competition in the US Market
hypotheses.description: Increased competition in the US market is driving up ad costs and reducing ROAS.
hypotheses.testable_prediction: The US market will have a lower ROAS compared to other countries (UK, IN). The cost per purchase (CPP) will be higher in the US during the analysis period compared to the comparison period.
supporting_evidence: US is a highly competitive market.
counterevidence: If the US has a higher ROAS than other countries.
If CPP has not increased in the US.
hypotheses.confidence_reasoning: The US market is often more competitive, leading to higher ad costs and potentially lower ROAS. This is especially true during peak seasons or promotional periods.

hypotheses.title: Budget Allocation Inefficiency
hypotheses.description: Inefficient budget allocation across campaigns/adsets is contributing to the ROAS drop. Some campaigns may be over-saturated while others are underfunded.
hypotheses.testable_prediction: Campaigns/adsets with the highest spend do not necessarily have the highest ROAS. A significant portion of the budget is allocated to underperforming campaigns.
supporting_evidence: Data includes 'spend' and 'roas' for each campaign/adset.
Diminishing returns are common with increased ad spend.
counterevidence: If campaigns with the highest spend also have the highest ROAS.
If there's a strong positive correlation between spend and ROAS.
hypotheses.confidence_reasoning: Budget allocation is crucial for maximizing ROAS. Inefficient allocation can lead to wasted spend and reduced overall performance.

priority_ranking.reason: Audience fatigue in retargeting is a common and easily testable issue. Refreshing creative or adjusting frequency capping can provide a quick win.
Creative decay is also a likely factor, especially if the video ads have been running for a while. Testing new video creative is relatively straightforward.
Market dynamics in the US can have a significant impact on ROAS. Understanding the competitive landscape and adjusting bids accordingly is important.
Budget allocation issues can be more complex to diagnose but can have a substantial impact on overall performance. Analyzing spend vs. ROAS across campaigns is a good starting point.

recommended_validations: Compare ROAS and CTR of retargeting adsets vs. other audience types using a t-test.
Analyze the ROAS trend of video ads over time to identify the point of decay.
Compare the ROAS and CPP in the US market to the UK and IN markets using a t-test.
Create a scatter plot of spend vs. ROAS for each campaign/adset to identify inefficient budget allocation.
thinking_process: I started by considering the common reasons for ROAS drops, such as audience fatigue, creative decay, and market dynamics. I then looked at the available data (audience types, creative types, countries) to see which of these factors were most likely to be contributing to the problem. I formulated hypotheses based on these factors and provided testable predictions that can be validated with the available data. Finally, I prioritized the hypotheses based on their likelihood and the ease of validation.
